holdings.text: An order made under Section 47(3) of the Motor Vehicles Act, 1939 is an 'order' within the meaning of Section 64-A against which a revision lies before the State Transport Authority.

anchor.surface_text: If we look at the section, it would be noticed that s. 64-A is very wide in terms the only condition necessary for filing a revision is that it should be against an order made by the Regional Transport Authority and against which no appeal lies. The word order is wide, and there is no doubt that an order made under s. 47 3

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 64-A has wide terms covering any order of RTA where no appeal lies; S.47(3) order qualifies as it binds RTA and STA in future permit considerations under ss.48/57, following precedent in Abdul Mateen v. Ram Kailash Pandey.

holdings.text: No existing operator can be aggrieved by an order under Section 47(3); whether aggrieved depends on facts and circumstances of each case if prejudicial to interests.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to say that no existing operator can be aggrieved by an order made under s. 47 3 , increasing or decreasing the number of stage carriages it would depend on the facts and circumstances of each case. In a particular case it may be to his advantage and he then would not file a revision against it, but if he files a revision when an order made under s. 47 3  is prejudicial to his interests, there is no ground for denying him the right to approach the revisional authority and seeking its order.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Order under S.47(3) affects future working on route with repercussions for existing operators; not automatic but case-specific if increase/decrease prejudices interests.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to decide whether existing operators are entitled to be heard by the Regional Transport Authority before passing an order under Section 47(3).

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, as stated above, was of the view that at the stage of s. 47 3 existing operators would not be entitled to be heard by the Regional Transport Authority. But assuming that it is so, this does not affect the right of revision conferred by s. 64-A. We need not in this case decide whether it is implied that existing operators would be entitled to be heard by the Regional Transport Authority before an order under s. 47 3  is made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue academic as right of revision under S.64-A exists independently even assuming no hearing right at S.47(3) stage.

holdings.text: In exercise of discretion under Article 136 of the Constitution, no interference with the High Court order is warranted.

anchor.surface_text: For the aforesaid reasons. in exercising our discretion under Art. 136 of the Constitution we consider that we should not interfere with the order passed by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Significant lapse of time (order of 1962); demand for stage carriages likely increased over five years; no evidence of glaring mistake by RTA; appellant never approached RTA initially.

anchor.surface_text: If we look at the section, it would be noticed that s. 64-A is very wide in terms the only condition necessary for filing a revision is that it should be against an order made by the Regional Transport Authority and against which no appeal lies. The word order is wide, and there is no doubt that an order made under s. 47 3
In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed. Under the circumstances there will be numberorder as to companyts.

edges.explanation: Holding h2 determines if existing operator is aggrieved under s.47(3), directly addressing issue i2.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to say that no existing operator can be aggrieved by an order made under s. 47 3 , increasing or decreasing the number of stage carriages it would depend on the facts and circumstances of each case. In a particular case it may be to his advantage and he then would not file a revision against it, but if he files a revision when an order made under s. 47 3  is prejudicial to his interests, there is no ground for denying him the right to approach the revisional authority and seeking its order.
In the result the appeal fails and is dismissed. Under the circumstances there will be numberorder as to companyts.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, as stated above, was of the view that at the stage of s. 47 3 existing operators would not be entitled to be heard by the Regional Transport Authority. But assuming that it is so, this does not affect the right of revision conferred by s. 64-A. We need not in this case decide whether it is implied that existing operators would be entitled to be heard by the Regional Transport Authority before an order under s. 47 3  is made.
